It would make more sense that they just have many orders of people only buying single slices instead of whole ones. After they make a whole pizza, cut it up, and put what their customers bought on a plate, they would still have the rest of that pizza left in the kitchen, so would make sense to add more slices to it when other customers order "whole" pizzas, instead of discarding the un-whole pizzas they have to always make a new whole pizza everytime people order.  If that's what they're doing, I like that because it minimizes waste, but I don't know why they don't just say that. Lots of restaurants have to throw out food when customers don't order enough. They use to donate it to the homeless here, but all places stopped doing that after they accidently donated expired food, so now they just leave it in the garbage and let the homeless take it on their own so they don't have to be legally liable.

He said they never recycled pizza (and me and my dad are really close so if they did heâ€™d tell me and Iâ€™d tell you right away ğŸ˜‚ğŸ˜­) he said that the reason it looks that way is because sometimes workers will get lazy and cook a full cheese and a full pepperoni and put a half of the cheese and a half of the pepperoni together for a half and half pizza. Former Chuck E. Cheese pizza maker here â€” just to back up the theory â€” the pizzas are handmade and hand tossed so sometimes they come out as an oval opposed to a circle. They donâ€™t use the traditional pizza cutters that is used with only one hand, they use a two-handed cutter. Cutting the pizza 100% evenly can be a bit difficult as mentioned in the video, yes this particular pizza cutter has some weight, also when the kitchen is ran by 16 year olds it can get very hectic and the pizzas would come out in all sorts of shapes LMAO, but never reused. The location I worked for at least was pretty sanitary and we did not recycle pizza :)

I love your content. and on how the pizza slices don't match up can be from the cutting board they use. when i worked for shark dining at nova southeastern university. we used to get papa johnâ€™s pizza at the private school on campus. we used a cutting board to make the slices. an if the person didn't re-center the pizza every time you made a cut it would push the segments around. in turn making the slices uneven and not line up. so, the real test would be getting the pizza uncut and use the same kind of cutting board at home and see if you can do it.

19:00 ... yes.. I get it.
Yilan County Council in Taiwan passed a cross-party motion on December 24 to support the Universal Declaration on Combating and Preventing Forced Organ Harvesting (UDCPFOH). The motion condemns the organ harvesting by the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and urges the Taiwan government to implement laws to help end the atrocity.    Chang Chiu-ming, a member of Yilan County Council, said a motion was passed on December 24 against organ harvesting.   When the 76th United Nations General Assembly took place in New York in September 2021, five nongovernmental organizations from the US, Europe, and Asia issued UDCPFOH on September 26, the last day of the World Summit on Combating and Preventing Forced Organ Harvesting.   UDCPFOH has been supported by parliament members, government officials, and leaders from many countries. They include Changrok Soh, member of UN Human Rights Council, and Thierry Valle, director of European Federation for Freedom of Belief. It was also endorsed by Arthur Caplan, professor of bioethics at New York University and the founding director of the Medical Ethics Division.   The Taiwan Falun Gong Human Rights Working Group has since contacted the central government as well as county-level governments in Taiwan, urging them to support this initiative. The Group believes that by raising awareness to the general public and taking further actions, leaders from around the world can stop the CCPâ€™s organ harvesting through joint efforts.   During an ad hoc session held by Yilan County Council on December 24, the motion was initiated by three council members including Zhang Chiu-ming, Chen Han-chung, and Tsai Chin-hui. To fulfill its human rights commitment, the motion aims to support the UDCPFOH, condemn the organ harvesting atrocity by the CCP, and institute related criminal legislation. For specific implementation of this resolution, the council requests the county government to contact relevant agencies of the Taiwan Executive Yuan. With 25 cosponsors, including Wu Hong-mo and Yang Tree, this motion was passed in the council.   Chang said he was happy to see Yilan Council supporting the upright with this motion. Yang pointed out the CCPâ€™s brutality of organ harvesting is anti-humanity and it is a disgrace to mankind. He hopes such efforts will stop the atrocity and promote kindness as well as traditional values in society.   All articles, graphics, and content published on Minghui.org are copyrighted. Non-commercial reproduction is allowed but requires attribution with the article title and a link to the original article.

Hi Shane, so, i used to work in a chuck E. Cheese's in Mexico, and i can confirm to you that that's not a thing. It's just the way the workers cut and SERVE the pizza, i used to cut the pizzas right after they go out of the oven, put them in a board, cut them, AND THEN place them in a plate, the pizza it's still hot, the cheese it's melted, thats when you transfer the pizza in to a plate the pieces move, and that's why they look like that. We cut it, before we serve it.

Okay so they're different sizes as when they cut the pizza as its fresh dough and it'll have different densitys throughout the pizza so once it's cooked and cools each slice would settle differently once it begins to cool, causing some slices to be smaller or bigger than the rest.. plus I imagine the cheese would have contributed to that fact as you are cooking out the moisture so it would dry smaller than the cheese before and more firm contorting the size of the pizza and as it cools after its been sliced. And  it could contribute to the mishapen slices...also other stores have they're dough made in factory's while chucke cheese does it in store which could further effect the prossess as far as shape and densitys of each slice... its weird but can be explained. I think the pizzas are wonky cause they sell slices. So when some person orders a pizza, they combine the pieces that are left from the pizzas that were ready (but with some slices missing cause they were sold individually). So basically, they don't make a fresh pizza when you order one since they already have all the other ones they made but with some pieces missing. It's not recycling, it's just more efficient then cooking it on the spot. Does that make sense?

When you did the first chuck e Cheese video, I remember seeing quite a few employees and ex employees say that the reason it looks like that is bc they do, in fact, consolidate the pizzas.. however, they don't make them out of pizza left at tables, they do it with pizzas that have only ever been behind the counter with employees. (Meaning that say someone orders like 6 slices, and then the next person orders 4, they need to take them from separate pizzas, leaving each with leftover pieces, then they would put THOSE together and I guess reheat it..?) Idk but the bottom line was that customers never touch the pizzas they consolidate. And tbh I believe it. Bc it makes sense and I just can't see a business of that size taking that kind of risk. Revelation states 21:8 "But the fearful, and unbelieving, and the abominable, and murderers, and whoremongers, and sorcerers, and idolaters, and all liars, shall have their part in the lake which burneth with fire and brimstone: which is the second death.". God sent his Son, Jesus, to Earth as a perfect sinless sacrifice. To take on all the sins of the world; both past, present, and future sins. Shedding his blood on the cross as a blood atonement for all sins. After dying on the cross, he rose from the dead on the 3rd day and rose to Heaven. To show life after death. To show everlasting life through Jesus's sacrifice. John 14:6 states: "Jesus saith unto him, I am the way, the truth, and the life: no man cometh unto the Father, but by me.". Romans 10:13 states "For whosoever shall call upon the name of the Lord shall be saved.".      Eternal life in heaven is just one prayer away. All you have to do is believe that Jesus Christ, the Son of God, died on the cross for your sins. As an atonement for your sins. And rose from the grave on the 3rd day. Ask Jesus to save you of your sins and give you eternal life in Heaven. Salvation is a free and everlasting gift from God. Please don't let pride drag you into eternal punishment in Hell, but ask Jesus to give you eternal life in Heaven. If you're getting a strong feeling of resistance while reading this, it's because Satan doesn't want you to get saved. He wants you to resist, and think it's not real. serious wedding advice: SET A DATE!!!!!!! find a venue you like, see how many people it will fit, and what their availability is like. 100% easier to do everything else once you can start telling vendors and guests when/where to go. dont worry about how "wedding" it feels. we chose a bird sanctuary because it wasnt a basic venue, and it was so much cheaper than a traditional hall reception. using a wedding app helps to keep a list, and it populates all the things you could consider, and you tailor them to which ones you want to use. planning is the worst, part, but getting it set makes the rest easy.

Mattpat did a video on his food theory Channel on why this happens, and its basically because the way they move the pizza from the oven to a cutting board isn't the smoothest so while it's still extremely hot it moves around a bit, and also the cutter they use is incredibly dull for safety reasons, and the force thy need to push down with to cut it also moves it out of place while it's still so hot and that force compressed the pizza in on itself a bit

As someone who lives in Colorado, I can say for sure I've never heard anyone say "howdy" in any way other than a joke or impression of someone from... somewhere else.  Having a truck can be nice though, especially when we're in the season we are now where it was 60 yesterday and today we have a winter storm advisory. And then it'll get up to being hot enough to melt the snow and it'll become a gross, slushy mess and then repeat numerous times until spring proper comes around. Then it does that again between fall and winter too but with more hot than cold. Our family gave them the name the "Early/Late Bi-polar Season" as if Colorado had some kind of brain controlling the weather.   That name actually came about with a family member with a bi-polar disorder of some kind (like a lot of mental things there's a rather wide and really hard to accurately use a lotta the time and I don't think she ever told me specifically what it is) said, "Oh hey, just like me!" when discussing the flip-floppy nature of Colorado's weather. I'm not sure if that also happens in the mountains but in the 3/4ths that is flat that's usually how it be.

I work in a pizza place weâ€™re we make everything by hand like dough and sauce and such. A 16 inch just cheese pizza , hand tossed sauced and topped maybe takes 5 minutes give or take and an additional 10 minutes in the oven. Multiple pizzas can cause the cook time to go up but only by a few minutes. If we had a fully loaded oven and the oven is not at temp it can take an additional 10 to 15 minutes depending on whatâ€™s going in. If you donâ€™t let it cool down right out of the oven, the cheese will cool between the pieces and make it look odd. I'm gonna assume that the pizza is recycled BUT not from anyone's plate or anything gross. In some places (countries), like where I'm from, we have the option to order single slices or a whole pie. I don't know how Chuckecheese does it, but I'm assuming if they have people ordering single slices. they would still bake the whole pie and serve whatever the customer wants. The left overs from that pie are still clean and not contaminated, so if someone orders a half and half pie, they would use that instead of baking another fresh pie when they still have some left from a previous pie that are still clean and edible. In short, instead of throwing away good parts of a whole pie away, they would still serve it, top it off with cheese and reheat it. Which I think, is ACCEPTABLE. Maybe the PR from chuckecheese didn't want to admit it since not a lot of people would accept it, and might think it still GROSS when in reality, it's reducing food waste. That is possibly why some parts of the pie aren't consistent in sizes, I highly doubt they would be serving pizza from someone else's plate or any pie that has any contact from a customer.

found thru a google search, an ex employee said â€œChuck E. Cheese requires all their pizzas to have the same number of slices. The magic number, in this case, is 12, but since the dough is made fresh in the kitchen, the pizzas donâ€™t come out perfectly circular. When they start cutting the pizzas, thereâ€™s not always the right number of slices and some slices come out larger than others. To compensate, some slices are cut in half and rearranged to create a whole pizza with exactly 12 slices.â€

Yea, the whole earth trembles when I pass by, for I am great in power and My glory has no equal! Thus the fear of The Lord goes before Me, and obedience follows after Me, says The Lord. Yet you peoples of the earth have turned from Me, and have rebelled against Me days without end! Thus I call upon the sons of men, even all who dwell upon the earth, to repent, to turn from your wicked ways, to bring forth new works worthy of repentance... Oh that justice would well up like water, and righteousness as an ever-flowing stream.[1] Yet you will not listen, you refuse to hear! WAYWARD GENERATION! Good to see you on this channel again, been watching and enjoying y'all on rylands channel. As a former pizza shop employee I'm gonna make a guess as to why the pizzas look uneven, the cutting board they use called a "peel" to cut the pizzas on then slide them into the box post cut. We did this at a pizza restaurant I worked at (Marco's Pizza) and it often looked similar. This causes the slices to jam into each other and look a little wonky. It makes for a faster cutting process and less damage to your cutting table tho I guess.

Ok... As someone whom cooks lot and has worked in multiple restaurants, when cutting a pizza, the cheese easily moves with the knife which makes the pepperoni look unaligned and not even. When a pizza has homemade crust, some make it not a perfect circle on purpose because it looks more homemade. Which makes slices not look even when cut. This is my assumption and answer from what I've encountered.

With the pizza conspiracy at least with the half and half pizza, as someone who works in food (not at Chuck e cheese) we're not allowed to put pepperonis on cheese pizza and cook it for a half and half pizza, you have to make one whole cheese and one whole pepperoni and then take half of each pizza for a half and half pizza which is why half and half pizzas often look wacky .

Love this! PLEASE bring back conspiracy documentary videos!!!! PLEEEEEASE!!!!!
I worked at a pizza place and honestly it's pretty easy to explain why the pizza looks like that, imo. If they didnt make their dough perfectly circular prior to baking, pieces can end up being different sizes. If the tool they are using to cut the pizzas isn't sharp enough or they are cutting too quickly, things can shift around and little slivers can end up missing (like if you cut a pizza at home and dont quite go over the same cut, you end up with little slivers missing). So i would say it's more common than people think for pizza to be a little wonky. MatPat did a video on Food Theory testing Chuck E Cheese pizzas, when they weren't doing dine in, and the pizzas still sometimes were a bit wonky. They can't be recycling pizza if no one is eating in the restaurant :)  I do agree that some of the pizzas floating around online from probably years ago have no explanation to why they look that way. But at least the ones they had in this video were honestly pretty normal

The reason they are all mix match and don't seem to fit is bc the dough gets hand stretched before the sauce gets placed (its never beautiful lol) and once it comes out it gets sliced seconds after pulled off the belt so once it's cooled down some it stays in the place it was left (giving some gaps). I know i am not from the US and I probably donâ€™t have a say nor does anyone want my opinion but i think the quality of chuck e cheeseâ€™s pizza is poor. There are standards businesses (especially food businesses) have to meet for their customers. Even if the pizza is cheap and is just â€œkids foodâ€. Every single pizza, even the ones made myself, has never been in a state where there are gaps between slices and edges of the pizzas being further out than others. These types of things is just not what happens when a fresh pizza is made to order. Youâ€™ll probably have a better quality pizza from a frozen pizza in a supermarket. Honestly, it is truly appalling. Someone really needs to stand up against this company. Chuck e cheese is a huge chain of restaurants and probably will pay their way through lawsuits and claims. It is very unfair on the customer. It is ridiculous how a food company makes excuses for things like this. That pizza was not made to order, it wasnâ€™t freshly made. Whether the pizza has moved in its box in transit or moved from when it was took out of the oven, no. Things like this does not happen. A freshly cut pizzas slices should slot together perfectly, all be the same length slices and not move away from each other during transit. I 100% believe they are using recycled pizza and putting fresh cheese and toppings to make it look fresh. This is how bacterial infections and food intoxications spread and can make customers very ill. It is poor hygiene and does not meet the correct health and safety regulations for the consumer. I am sorry to the Americans that have to put up with it. Donâ€™t mean to offend anyone, just solely my opinion :)

OMG SHANE POSTED
Hi, Shane, I'm so glad to see you back! You look so genuinely happy! I do want to say one thing though about the pizzas. I never worked for Chuck E Cheese, but I did work as a manager for Pizza Hut for a year and that included having to make the pizzas as well as cut them so I've got a little bit of knowledge behind it. From what I was able to see of the pizzas (As the footage was usually quick and not really focused) they are actually made perfectly. I can see where when the person used the cutter that it might have pushed the pieces apart and the hot cheese slid in between and solidified making it so that the pieces would join back together and stay. The smaller pieces of pizza is just simply from how they cut the pizza. I've cut really thin slices before as its hard to cut the slices equally. In comparison to the pizzas from a few years ago which did look a bit sketchy, these ones are made perfectly! Hope that answers some of your questions!

I cannot believe this still needs to be saidâ€¦the CEC pizza is NOT and will never be recycled. They are held to the same food and health sanitation standards as any other restaurant. I worked in a lead position at the company for 5 yrs.  #1: the dough is literally shaped by hand by 16-18yo kids (most of the time) which is then sauced by hand and not always symmetrical.   #2: the crust is put on a screen before going into the oven and the dough will stick to the screen if not enough semolina is used. Sometimes the bottom of the pizza needs to be scraped from the screen and part of the pizza may come off.  #3: when the pizza comes out of the oven, itâ€™s 500 degrees and the cheese and toppings slide very easily. When itâ€™s cut, sometimes the cheese or toppings slide off and get stuck on the large knife or cutting board which is why youâ€™ll sometimes see half a pepperoni slice.   Please keep in mind that the kitchen staff at CEC are typically HS students who arenâ€™t qualified and trained chefs.
